messages.content: What's today's entry? Probably around 5 a.m. Feeling better, but I stayed on the bed until 5 a.m. So because last night I had a migraine attack, and then this morning I woke up with my SEM muscle on the right side very tender and tight. The headache is fairly clear.

Log saved FieldDetailsDate2025-08-06Time05 : 00LocationFrederick, MDWeather Currently 68° · Mostly cloudyFrederick, MD, United States6 AM65°Cloudy7 AM66°Cloudy8 AM70°Mostly cloudy9 AM72°Mostly cloudy10 AM75°Mostly cloudy11 AM76°Cloudy12 PM78°Cloudy1 PM79°CloudyShow more | | Bed time (HH:MM) | | | Wake time (HH:MM) | 05 : 00 | | Sleep hours + Quality (1-10) | | | Night wakes (#) | | | Morning light (min) | | | Weight (lbs) | | | AM-feel refreshed (1-10) | | | Meals & times (food, caffeine, alcohol) | | | Hydration (oz) | | | Stress (0-10) | | | Mood / emotions | Feeling better | | Exercise / Activity | | | Posture breaks / Neck exercises | | | Notes (weather change, hormones, travel, etc.) | Right SCM muscle tender/tight; migraine attack last night; headache clear this morning | | Protein (g) | | | Vitamin D (IU) | | | Calcium (mg) | | | Calories (kcal) | | | Carbohydrates (g) | | | Added sugars (g) | | | Supplements list | | | Pantoprazole (Y/N time) | | | Famotidine (Y/N time) | | | Amitriptyline (Y/N time) | | | Emgality – injection date | | | Doxylamine (mg + brand) | | | Acetaminophen (mg + brand) | | | Right-side migraine pain (0-10) | 1 | | Left-headache pain (0-10) | 0 | | Scalp-pain (0-10) | 0 | | Asthma symptoms (none / cough / tight) | none | | Reflux symptoms (burn / lump / cool 0-5) | | | Episode ID link | | | PT Before pain / tightness (0-10) | | | PT During comfort (0-10) | | | PT After relief (0-10) | | | Dry-mouth (0-5) | | | Motivation (0-5) | | | Appetite (↓ / ↔ / ↑) | | | Maintenance inhaler (name + puffs) | | | Rescue inhaler uses | | Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
I also took my maintenance inhaler around 5am ; and pantoprazole around 5am

Log saved FieldDetailsPantoprazole (Y/N time)Y @ 05:00Maintenance inhaler (name + puffs)Fluticasone/Salmeterol DPI – took @ 05:00 (puffs ?) Reflections Tender right-SCM after a migraine often hints at neck-muscle guarding. A mini-experiment today: apply a warm pack, then do two 30-sec gentle lateral neck stretches (ear → shoulder) on each side and note any change in tenderness or head pain tomorrow. Regular light exercise and warm-ups are linked to fewer migraine days . Quick info check: How many hours did you sleep (quality 1-10) and how much water have you had so far? Also, how many puffs of the maintenance inhaler did you take at 05:00? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
I decided to apply some heat therapy around 05:35am ; socks filled with rice and heat in microwave for 1min

Log saved FieldDetailsPosture breaks / Neck exercisesHeat therapy – rice-sock @ 05:35 for right SCM Reflections Nice job adding heat early; that warmth can boost local blood flow and relax the SCM. After the pack cools, consider two slow chin-tuck holds (10 sec each) to reinforce lengthening. Still looking for: number of puffs of maintenance inhaler at 05:00, last night’s sleep hours + quality, and how much water you’ve had so far—all helpful to spot patterns. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
1 puff, only 1pull needed; sleep hours would be from 9pm to 4am ; quality =5; water drank 8oz+ 8oz (electornlyte mixed)

Log saved FieldDetailsBed time (HH:MM)21:00Wake time (HH:MM)04:00Sleep hours + Quality (1-10)7 h; 5/10Hydration (oz)16Maintenance inhaler (name + puffs)Fluticasone/Salmeterol DPI – 1 puff @ 05:00 Reflections Solid 7 hours in bed, but the middling quality (5/10) plus early-morning SCM tension hints sleep posture may still be a trigger. Tonight try a thin extra pillow under the right shoulder to off-load neck strain and re-rate quality tomorrow. Hydration’s at 16 oz—great start, yet you’ll want ~64 oz by dinner to keep muscles and airways happier. Aim for another 16 oz before noon. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
it's not from sleep posture, it's from the migraine attack from last night

Log saved FieldDetailsEpisode ID linkMigraine _2025-08-05_evening – need start/end, peak level & relief details Reflections Got it—SCM tightness can indeed be part of the migraine cascade rather than a pillow issue. Your PCP’s July note lists “sternocleidomastoid muscle tenderness” under the same visit that documented intractable migraine , and post-drome studies show lingering muscle and sensory symptoms for hours-to-days after the head pain resolves . Micro-experiment: when the next attack starts, jot the exact clock-time when (a) head pain begins, (b) SCM first feels tight, and (c) heat or stretch gives relief. Over 2-3 attacks we’ll see if muscle work earlier shortens the whole episode. Quick check so the episode row is complete: When did last night’s migraine start and fully end (or current pain level if it’s still fading)? What was the worst pain (0-10) and did you take any meds/techniques that clearly helped? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
he right side of head feel a bit pain on the temple area, not because of the stretches, I did some neck stretching, chin tuck, trapezius, levator scapulae, SCM stretch;

Log saved FieldDetailsPosture breaks / Neck exercisesAdded neck stretching – chin-tuck, trapezius, levator-scapulae, SCM @ ≈ 06:00Right-side migraine pain (0-10)“Bit of pain” at right temple → need exact 0-10 Reflections Muscle-focused stretches right after heat are often helpful in the post-drome; nice sequence. Monitor whether temple discomfort eases within 30 min—if it worsens toward 4-5/10, consider rescue strategies sooner. Quick clarifier: what number (0-10) best describes that current right-temple pain, and is it trending up, stable, or down? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
here's my breakfast at 05:35am: 1c kashigo cereal + 1c 1%milk + 30 blueberries + 1/4 teaspoon chia seeds

Log saved FieldDetailsMeals & times (food, caffeine, alcohol)05:35 — 1 c Kashi GO cereal + 1 c 1 % milk + ≈30 blueberries + ¼ tsp chia seedsProtein (g)~21 g (cereal 12 g + milk 8 g + fruits/seeds 1 g)Vitamin D (IU)~115 IU (fortified milk)Calcium (mg)~325 mg (milk 300 mg + chia 25 mg)Calories (kcal)~295 kcalCarbohydrates (g)~50 gAdded sugars (g)~7 g (from cereal) Reflections Well-rounded breakfast: solid 21 g protein and a good calcium/Vit D boost from dairy set your muscles and nerves up for the day. Blueberry polyphenols may even have neuro-protective benefits. Only ~7 g added sugar—nice. Keep total < 25 g today to avoid rebound energy dips that can aggravate migraine biochemistry (Megahandout p38). Still need the exact right-temple pain rating (0-10) to finish the episode log; noting that number helps track whether post-drome tightness is easing. Morning light + hydration: you’re at 16 oz—aim for another 16 oz by 10 a.m., and grab at least 5 min outdoor light to stabilize circadian cortisol. Clinician disclaimer: reflections are educational, not medical advice. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
I had two fried eggs

Log saved FieldDetailsMeals & times (food, caffeine, alcohol)05 : 35 — 1 c Kashi GO cereal + 1 c 1 % milk + ≈30 blueberries + ¼ tsp chia seeds + 2 fried eggsProtein (g)33 g (21 g prior + ~12 g eggs)Vitamin D (IU)≈ 197 IU (115 IU prior + ~82 IU eggs)Calcium (mg)≈ 353 mg (325 mg prior + ~28 mg eggs)Calories (kcal)≈ 439 kcal (295 kcal prior + ~144 kcal eggs) Reflections The two eggs bump your breakfast protein to 33 g, a strong start toward the ≥ 70 g daily target that supports muscle recovery and migraine-protective neurotransmitter balance (Megahandout p 42). Still need the exact right-temple pain rating (0-10) to finish logging last night’s episode and watch the post-drome trend—could you give that number? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
I have been caffeine free for 3 days but I am having rouble to poop and should I start to drink a Lipitor but coffee today?

Log saved FieldDetailsNotes (weather change, hormones, travel, etc.)Constipation; caffeine-free × 3 days Reflections Constipation + caffeine pause. A small (≤ 6 oz) cup of coffee can stimulate colon motility for many people, yet more than ~2 cups/day raises migraine risk for sensitive brains . If you choose to re-introduce it, start with one short cup, ideally after breakfast (never fasted) and track both bowel results and any head-pain shifts for 24 h. Non-caffeine options first. Make sure today’s fluid goal (~64 oz), a brisk 10-min walk, and ≥ 25 g fiber (fruit + veg + whole grains) are in place. Your nightly magnesium (120 mg) is gentle, but switching one dose to magnesium oxide or citrate occasionally adds laxative effect—loose stools are the common side-effect to watch . Still need: exact right-temple pain number (0-10) to close the episode log, and tell me if you end up drinking that trial coffee so we can capture caffeine intake. Clinician disclaimer: educational only, not medical advice. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

I'm feeling a bit of low motivation. The thing is that... I don't know, it's a little bit uncomfortable today, but somehow I think it's hard for me to focus or concentrate to do something productive. Yeah.

Log saved FieldDetailsMood / emotionsLow motivation, hard to focus Reflections A dip in motivation and mental clarity is common in the post-drome phase (the “migraine hangover”). Light movement (5-min walk or gentle yoga) plus 2-min diaphragmatic breathing can boost oxygenation and catecholamines, often sharpening focus within 20 min (Megahandout p 57). Micro-experiment: pick a tiny, 3-minute task (e.g., tidy one shelf, draft one email). Start a timer, do just that, then stand up and stretch. Note if the brief success nudges motivation up a notch. Quick check so the log is complete: Current right-temple pain number (0-10)? Motivation score (0-5)? Stress level right now (0-10)? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
My supplement is Magnesium Glycinate. If I am already taking the that, can I still take Magnesium Citrate?

Log saved FieldDetailsSupplements listMagnesium glycinate 120 mg (daily) Reflections Combining forms is usually fine—watch the total dose & bowels. Magnesium glycinate is well-absorbed and gentle on the gut, while magnesium citrate is more osmotic, so it helps move the bowels but can tip you into loose stools if the total elemental Mg climbs too high. Clinical migraine guidelines cite ≈ 400-600 mg elemental Mg/day—often given as citrate 450-600 mg—to prevent attacks. If you add citrate, start with a half-dose (e.g., 150–200 mg elemental) taken separately from glycinate, then see how both your head and GI tract respond over 2-3 days. Red-flag for diarrhea: the Megahandout lists “diarrhea” as the main side-effect across magnesium salts, including diglycinate (glycinate) and other forms. Persistent loose stools, kidney disease, or very low blood pressure would be reasons to call your clinician before upping the dose. Quick prompts to complete today’s log: Right-temple pain 0-10 now? Motivation score 0-5? Current stress 0-10? Educational only—not medical advice. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
Is constipation any of the side effects I'm taking, the medications I'm having, supplements I'm having?

Log saved FieldDetails Reflections Likely culprits. Among your current meds, amitriptyline’s anticholinergic effect and calcium supplements are the two most common drivers of constipation. H₂-blockers like famotidine and PPIs like pantoprazole list it as a possible (though less frequent) side-effect; Emgality has scattered reports, but magnesium glycinate generally loosens stools, not the other way around. Tweaks to try (with your clinician’s OK): keep total elemental magnesium ≤ 400-600 mg/day but consider shifting part of it to magnesium citrate at night; stay ≥ 64 oz fluids, ≥ 25 g fiber, and fit in a 10-min brisk walk. If stools stay firm after 3–5 days, ask your PCP about lowering evening amitriptyline or switching to a calcium citrate + vitamin D combo that’s gentler on the gut. Quick check so the log is complete: right-temple pain 0-10, current stress (0-10), and motivation (0-5)? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

Okay, I finally pooped. I don't know, I feel pretty forced . It's very dry. I don't understand, I'm like drinking tons of water and so far I already have 40 ounces. Even yesterday I had probably over 100 ounces.

Log saved FieldDetailsNotes (weather change, hormones, travel, etc.)Forced, very-dry bowel movement this morning despite 40 oz water so far & ≥ 100 oz yesterday Reflections Why water alone wasn’t enough. Stool moisture depends on fiber + osmotic pull as much as raw fluid. Today’s breakfast had only ~7 g total fiber (Kashi GO 3 g, blueberries 4 g, chia 0.6 g); most adults need ≥ 25 g/day for soft, bulky stool. Eggs and dairy add zero fiber, so consider topping cereal with 1 Tbsp ground flax (2 g fiber) or adding a kiwi or 4–5 prunes mid-morning. Leverage magnesium form. Glycinate is gentle and absorbed into muscle, so it rarely loosens stools. Magnesium citrate is specifically listed as causing loose stools/diarrhea among migraine-friendly salts . Swapping 150-200 mg of your evening glycinate for citrate every other night can draw water into the colon without exceeding the 400–600 mg elemental daily ceiling. Movement matters. A 10-minute brisk walk or two sets of 20 body-weight squats stimulate colonic motility; pair that with your next 16 oz of water. Quick check to finish today’s log: Current right-temple pain (0-10)? Motivation (0-5) and stress (0-10) right now? Did you try coffee yet—and if so, how much? Educational only—please consult your clinician for personalized advice. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
Can I eat a flax seed, ground flax seed, or kiwi? Do they have migraine risks?

Log saved FieldDetails Reflections Flaxseed (whole or ground) isn’t on most trigger lists; in fact, its omega-3s and lignans are studied for protective anti-inflammatory effects in migraine and other vascular headaches. Kiwi shows up in some elimination-diet “caution” columns—alongside citrus, bananas, raspberries—because a minority of patients report it as a personal trigger, though it isn’t high in tyramine or histamine. If you’ve never linked kiwi to attacks, it’s reasonable to test: add one kiwi (or 1 Tbsp ground flax) on a low-trigger day, keep everything else routine, and watch symptoms for 24 h. If no change after three tries, it’s likely safe for you. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
What are the fruits that I cannot eat ? Or vegetables ? For migraines only

Below is a starter “watch-list” drawn from peer-reviewed migraine‐diet handouts and recent elimination-diet guides. Remember: these foods only cause trouble in some people—your own log will tell us which ones matter for you. Fruits that most often act up Tyramine-rich or histamine-rich, especially if over-ripe or dried Avocado Banana (especially speckled or brown) Papaya, pineapple, passion fruit Red or dark plums, prunes, raisins, currants, dates Grapes (sulfites) Citrus (orange, grapefruit, lemon, lime) ➜ keep to ≤ ½ cup juice or 1 whole fruit at a time Raspberries, strawberries, cherries (histamine) Any over-ripe or sulfite-treated dried fruit Vegetables / legumes to be cautious with Tyramine / histamine / nitrite group Tomato & all tomato products Spinach, eggplant, olives Beet, red potato, sweet potato (nitrates/tyramine) Fava or broad beans, snow peas, green peas, navy/pinto/lima beans (if sensitive to tyramine) Onion & garlic (listed on several traditional migraine diets) Sauerkraut, pickles, other fermented/pickled veg Why these come up Tyramine & histamine build up as produce ripens/ferments and can provoke the trigemino-vascular system in susceptible brains. Sulfites & nitrates/nitrites (used to preserve color or occur naturally) can dilate blood vessels or release nitric oxide—another common pathway in migraine. Personal thresholds vary. Many people tolerate small portions—e.g., ½ cup fresh citrus—without issues. How to use the list Eliminate for 2 weeks the items you eat most often. Re-introduce one at a time (e.g., 1 kiwi at breakfast, nothing new for 24 h). Log headache intensity, neck stiffness, and GI changes—your tracker will flag patterns better than any generic list. Good news: flaxseed, kiwi, most lettuces, carrots, zucchini, cucumbers, berries in moderation, and the majority of non-nightshade veggies are usually migraine-safe—and high-fiber choices like kiwi or 1 Tbsp ground flax can also ease constipation without triggering most migraineurs. Always tailor changes with your clinician or dietitian, especially if other conditions (reflux, IBS, kidney issues) are in play. Any of the foods above show up frequently in your own meals? If yes, we can plan a simple A/B test in the log. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
Motivation really low -1

Log saved FieldDetailsMotivation (0-5)“–1” (reported)* *Our tracker scale runs 0 = none to 5 = very high. Let me know if 0 fits better, or tell me another number on that 0-5 scale and I’ll update it. Reflections A motivation dip that extreme often pairs with the post-drome “brain-fog + flat mood” window. Two quick boosts you can test today: Sunlight sprint: step outdoors for 5 min of natural light plus three deep belly breaths—research shows a 10-15 point jump in alertness ratings within 20 min. Victory-list: write one tiny task you already did (e.g., heated the rice sock), then cross it off—this primes the reward circuit and can lift motivation one notch. Still missing pieces to finish today’s entry and spot patterns: Current right-temple pain (0-10)? Current stress level (0-10)? Did you trial any coffee today—yes/no and how much? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
So I intend to buy this whole wheat bread. Is there any ingredient I should not eat for migraine?

Log saved FieldDetails (no new rows this turn) Reflections Scan of the label shows no “big-five” migraine triggers (aged cheese, nitrates, MSG, artificial sweeteners, chocolate). The only possibles are the calcium propionate preservative and naturally yeast/soy—they bother a minority of people, so watch your own pattern. Low-risk test: try one slice on a calm, low-trigger day; log head/neck status for 24 h. No change after three separate trials → bread is likely safe for you. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

Okay, here's my lunch. I made a fried pork with green beans. It's one pound of pork and one pound of green bean. And also there's about 3-4 cup of rice. For the seasoning, there were one teaspoon dark soy sauce, one teaspoon light soy sauce. Not teaspoon, sorry, half a teaspoon of dark soy sauce and half a teaspoon of light soy sauce. And also I used one tablespoon of soybean paste. I had the entire lunch about two-fifth. The lunch happened between 11:30 am to 12

Log saved FieldDetailsMeals & times (food, caffeine, alcohol)11 : 30 – 12 : 00 — ate ≈ 2/5 of stir-fried pork + green beans (≈ 182 g pork, 182 g beans) with ~1.4 c cooked rice; seasonings: 0.2 tsp dark soy, 0.2 tsp light soy, 0.4 Tbsp soybean pasteProtein (g)86 g (33 g breakfast + ≈ 53 g lunch)Calories (kcal)≈ 1 090 kcal (cum)Carbohydrates (g)≈ 121 g (cum)Calcium (mg)≈ 403 mg (cum) Reflections Lunch pushes you past the 70 g daily protein goal—great for muscle repair and migraine-protective neurotransmitters. Note that fermented soy seasonings count as one “amine” trigger; stay under 2 amine servings today to keep your threshold safe. Quick check to round out today’s log: (1) Current right-temple pain 0-10? (2) Stress level right now 0-10? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
it's not just pork, it's ground pork.

Log saved FieldDetailsMeals & times (food, caffeine, alcohol)11 : 30 – 12 : 00 — ≈ 2/5 of ground pork-&-green-bean stir-fry (≈ 182 g ground pork, 182 g beans) + ~1.4 c cooked rice; 0.2 tsp dark soy, 0.2 tsp light soy, 0.4 Tbsp soybean paste Reflections Thanks for clarifying it was ground pork—slightly higher fat than lean cuts. Extra fat can slow gastric emptying; just keep an eye on any reflux or fullness this afternoon and balance later meals with lighter protein (e.g., fish or lentils). Still missing to close today’s entry: Current right-temple pain (0-10)? Current stress (0-10)? Any coffee yet—yes/no and amount? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
There's no pain, no right tempo pain. Stress level, I don't know, above 1. I'm a bit concerned about career and unemployment. Not sure what to do next. No coffee. I didn't have any coffee.

Log saved FieldDetailsRight-side migraine pain (0-10)0Stress (0-10)~2 (user said “above 1”; adjust if different) Reflections Career worries can feel heavy; try a 15-minute “brain-dump + next-step” sprint: set a timer, list every job/life thought swirling, circle one action you could take today (e.g., polish 1 résumé bullet, message 1 contact). Tiny progress often eases stress a full point or two. Quick clarifiers for the tracker: does “~2” feel right for stress on the 0-10 scale? And should your motivation entry read 0 (none) instead of “–1” on our 0-5 scale? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
I had a mid sized honey crisp apple for snack. I took a darkroom rest / nap, but I didn’t fall asleep between 1pm to 2pm

Log saved FieldDetailsMeals & times (food, caffeine, alcohol)05 : 35 — breakfast (cereal, milk, blueberries, chia, 2 eggs)11 : 30–12 : 00 — 2/5 serving ground-pork + green-bean stir-fry, 1.4 c rice13 : 00 — Honeycrisp apple (snack)Posture breaks / Neck exercisesDark-room rest (no sleep) 13 : 00-14 : 00Calories (kcal)≈ 1 185 kcal (cumulative)Carbohydrates (g)≈ 146 g (cumulative)Calcium (mg)≈ 414 mg (cumulative) Reflections Nice call on the apple: ~4 g soluble/insoluble fiber plus water content can soften stools without adding migraine-trigger amines. Quick check for the tracker: Hydration total so far (still 40 oz or higher?) Motivation number on our 0–5 scale (would 0 fit?) Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
water plus another 16 oz

Log saved FieldDetailsHydration (oz)56 Reflections Great—56 oz puts you within one tall glass of today’s 64 oz goal; pace another 8 oz before dinner to stay on track and help keep stools soft. Quick check: on our 0-5 scale, does 0 feel right for motivation, or would you choose another number? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
I did 40 min ring fit exercise from 02:30 pm - 03:30pm

Log saved FieldDetailsExercise / Activity40 min Ring Fit workout (14:30 – 15:30) Reflections Nice bump of circulation and endorphins—moderate cardio like Ring Fit often lifts mood for 2-4 h; notice whether motivation edges up afterward. Post-workout check-in: any asthma tightness or need for rescue inhaler? And on our 0-5 scale, what number best fits motivation right now? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
what do you think we swap our current vitamin b2 with this label ? a vitamin b complex , is it sufficient to compare the vitamine b2 I'm having ?

Log saved (no new rows this turn) Reflections The B-complex in the photo supplies 12.7 mg riboflavin (B2) per capsule. Migraine-prevention studies—and current American Headache Society guidance—use 400 mg/day (or occasionally 200 mg) to cut attack frequency. That’s ~30 times more than the complex provides, so it would not replace your stand-alone 400 mg B2; you’d need to keep the high-dose riboflavin or find a complex that nears that dose. A combo strategy some migraine patients use: stay on 400 mg riboflavin and add one B-complex a few times a week for the other Bs. Your label’s B-6 is 16.7 mg—well below the neuropathy-risk threshold (>100 mg/day), and niacin is “no-flush,” so both are generally safe at that level. Quick tracker prompts (max 2): Motivation score (0-5) now that you’ve exercised? Any asthma tightness or rescue inhaler uses after the Ring Fit session? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
what do you think of all the different vitamin bs, what are their benefits ? what would be helpful for my migraines

Log saved FieldDetails (no new rows this turn) Reflections Quick tour of the B-vitamins & migraine science B-vitaminTypical migraine-helpful doseMain jobsWhat the evidence saysB2 (Riboflavin)400 mg/day (often split AM/PM)Mitochondrial energy productionBest-studied; multiple RCTs and 2024 reviews show ≥ 50 % drop in attack frequency for many users after 8–12 wks.B6 (Pyridoxine)25–80 mg/day (keep < 100 mg)Cofactor for serotonin & homocysteine metabolismB6 + folate + B12 lowers homocysteine and cuts headache severity/frequency vs. placebo in several trials.Folate (B9) + B121–2 mg folate + 400 µg B12Re-methylates homocysteine; nerve myelinCombo with B6 shows additive migraine benefit, esp. in MTHFR C677T carriers; higher (2 mg) folate dose works better than 1 mg.B1 (Thiamine)50–100 mgGlucose → ATP; nerve conductionEarly data suggest deficiency worsens fatigue in migraine, but no large trials yet.B3 (Niacin/niacinamide)250–500 mg niacinamide, or SR niacin (titrated)Boosts NAD⁺, vasodilatesCase reports & small studies show prevention/abortive effects, but flushing limits routine use; research ongoing.B5 (Pantothenic acid)50–100 mgCo-enzyme A synthesisNo direct migraine data; usually included to balance B-complex.B7 (Biotin)300–1 000 µgFatty-acid metabolismNo migraine data; safe at listed doses. Take-home for your stack Your current 400 mg stand-alone B2 is the cornerstone—keep it. A B-complex like the one in the photo (12.7 mg B2) is fine in addition, to cover the other Bs, but it cannot replace the high-dose B2. If homocysteine-lowering is a goal (e.g., family vascular risk, aura), consider adding B6 25 mg + methyl-folate 1 mg + B12 400 µg daily or every other day—those doses match the trials that reduced migraine severity. Stay under safe upper limits: B6 < 100 mg/day (to avoid neuropathy); niacinamide < 3 g/day (liver); folate < 5 mg/day unless prescribed. Two quick prompts On our 0–5 motivation scale, would you log today’s value as 0? Any asthma tightness or rescue-inhaler use after your Ring Fit workout? Educational only—please confirm supplement changes with your clinician. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?
the morning was 0 but the afternoon was about 3 or 4 ; no asthma related symtomps

Log saved FieldDetailsMotivation (0-5)0 this morning → 4 after Ring Fit Reflections Nice surge in motivation after your 40-min workout—strong hint that midday movement is a mood lever for you. Try blocking a similar exercise window tomorrow and see if the boost repeats. With no asthma flare post-exercise, your maintenance inhaler timing seems effective. A quick win for the evening: add one high-fiber side (e.g., kiwi or 1 Tbsp ground flax in yogurt) plus 8 oz water to hit the 64 oz hydration goal and keep stools soft. Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

my left neck on the back where the scm starts near the skull, felt pretty tight and tender, it was a result of some movement I did when lying on bed earlier this afternoon ; I just did a group of neck stretches and those are helpful ; particularly the trapezius, levator scapulea

Log saved FieldDetailsPosture breaks / Neck exercisesAdded afternoon set of trapezius + levator-scapulae stretches for left upper-SCM tightnessNotes (weather change, hormones, travel, etc.)Left posterior-neck (SCM insertion) felt tight/tender after lying-down movement; stretches gave relief Reflections Great self-correction: levator-scap & upper-trap stretches often ease insertion-point tenderness within minutes. A warm pack first can boost the effect if it lingers this evening. To finish logging this mini-flare: What number (0-10) best describes that left-neck pain/tightness at its worst? About what time did it start and how long did relief last after the stretches? (Needed for the Episode summary.) Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

So dinner, I made a salad. The salad is made out of probably 2 cups of arugula, 2 cups of iceberg lettuce, a dozen of cherry tomatoes, and about 1 quarter of red onions sliced. And the dressing is olive oil, balsamic vinegar, lemon juice, salt and pepper. I had about half of that salad. And then I made a tofu steak, which is a box of tofu. And then the sauce is 2 teaspoons of white cooking wine, 2 teaspoons of mirin, and 2 teaspoons of light soy sauce. And then it was cooked fried with garlic and 1 tablespoon of butter. And then also I had 2 toasted whole wheat bread. The whole wheat bread has together 10 grams of protein and 6 grams of fiber. And then the dinner was between 6 to 6.30 p.m.

Log saved FieldDetailsMeals & times (food, caffeine, alcohol)05 : 35 — breakfast (cereal + milk, blueberries, chia, 2 eggs) · 11 : 30-12 : 00 — 2/5 ground-pork + green-bean stir-fry, 1.4 c rice · 13 : 00 — Honeycrisp apple · 18 : 00-18 : 30 — ½ salad (2 c arugula, 2 c iceberg, 6 cherry tomatoes, ⅛ red onion, olive-oil/balsamic/lemon dressing) + 1 tofu “steak” (14 oz) with garlic, 1 Tbsp butter, sauce (2 tsp cooking wine, 2 tsp mirin, 2 tsp light soy) + 2 slices whole-wheat breadProtein (g)≈ 138 gVitamin D (IU)≈ 212 IUCalcium (mg)≈ 1 409 mgCalories (kcal)≈ 1 920 kcalCarbohydrates (g)≈ 181 gAdded sugars (g)≈ 12 g Reflections Dinner bumps calcium past 1 000 mg (tofu ≈ 835 mg) and protein to ~138 g—excellent for muscle recovery. The mirin/soy combo is your second amine exposure today; stay clear of a third to keep within your trigger threshold. To wrap the day’s episode log: what was the peak left-neck pain/tightness (0-10), about what time did it start, and how long did relief last after those stretches? Stretch, deep breath, quick walk?

There was some left neck pain after dinner with like one, but I did some neck exercise stretching. I think that helped resolve it. It started about, to be honest, just like a little bit pain. I think it's still there. I just need to be careful and not trigger it. Started probably 6 p.m. and resolved at 7 p.m. The stretches really helped.
